bibl.title: Letter from Harvey Cushing to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 1, 1925

div1.p: Cushing congratulates Kean for his review of the Gorgas biography. An autograph note by Kean reveals sales statistics of both the Osler and Gorgas biographies.

div1.head: Letter from Harvey Cushing to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 1, 1925
div1.opener:
JOSEPH B. HOWLAND, M. D.
SUPERINTENDENT
HENRY A. CHRISTIAN, M. D.
PHYSICIAN-IN-CHIEF
HARVEY CUSHING, M. D.
SURGEON-IN-CHIEF
S. BURT WOLBACH, M. D.
PATHOLOGIST
PETER BENT BRIGHAM HOSPITAL
721 HUNTINGTON AVENUE
BOSTON 17, MASS.
July 1, 1925
Pen file
Assoc'n Military Surgeons,U.S.
JUL 3 1925
Secretary-Treasurer's Office.
Colonel J. R. Kean
Army Medical Museum
Washington, D. C.
Dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
Thanks much for your note. I am
delighted to see your editorial on the biography of
Gorgas. I think you are quite right in coming to the
defence of Reed. As a matter of fact, I was quite
disappointed in the biography. But Heaven help me,
having perpetrated one myself, I have compassion on
biographers in general. The difference in point of
view is that Mrs. Gorgas and Hendrick in combination
have tried to make an ideal person out of their hero
whereas I have merely tried to let Osler show what
he was like by permitting the story to unravel itself.
The fault in my method which the reviewers may justly
criticize, and severely, is that I have taken too many
pages to do this and few people will have the patience
to read the story through to the end, or even to turn
the pages.

I shall be very much interested to see how the two
books sell, for they have come out at about the same
time. The Osler volumes, being printed in England, are
undoubtedly expensive over here, and the Oxford Press
have not utilized or had at their command the ordinary
medium of advertising such as Doubleday Page & Co. have
access to. It would be interesting to know at the end *
of six months something about the comparison of the *
sales, for after all the success must be measured by *
readers rather than by reviewers.

Cushing's Osler was all sold out and a new printing was necessary
The Gorgas-Hendrick biography was so widely condemned that it failed to sell
There was no reprint of it & the copyright was sold- It is now rarely seen
a case reprint later (B)

But I didn't set out to write you about the Osler
but merely to commend you on your admirable and timely
editorial.
With great regards, I am as always

closer.seg:
P.S. I wish to the dickens I had recalled that your
office was in the Museum Building. Otherwise I would
have looked in on you a few weeks ago when I was in
Washington at the time of the Congress. I called
on the General, but he was out at lunch; and when in
the Library I was got hooked by the nose and spent
the morning looking at some old books.
